Pre-Game Insights: Both teams have shown defensive fragility in their recent outings.
Benin’s attack largely revolves around Steve Mounie, who averages two shots on target per game.
Libya have been able to score in most of their recent matches, netting in six of their last seven games.
Benin’s record of just two clean sheets in their last 11 matches further underlines the likelihood of Libya breaking through at least once.
Benin’s recent form in AFCON qualifiers paints a picture of a team that concedes often but also scores.
Both teams are desperate for points in this qualifier, and this urgency should make for an open, attacking game.
Both teams to score is a strong bet, given Benin's attacking threat through Mounie and Libya’s defensive struggles.
Libya's scoring capability and Benin’s defensive vulnerabilities suggest goals at both ends.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Both teams have struggled to keep clean sheets in recent matches.
Benin's Steve Mounie remains a significant threat to Libya’s defence.
Libya's creative forward line featuring players like Ahmed Krawaa will likely trouble a Benin defence that has been far from solid.
Benin's ability to break down defences, particularly at home, could be the deciding factor.
Libya's poor defensive record makes a narrow 2-1 victory the most plausible outcome for Benin.
Others: Emmanuel Nwankwo from BettingTips4You.com predicts that both teams will score.
Benin's overall quality, especially in attack, makes a narrow 2-1 victory the most plausible outcome.
Benin and Libya will face off at Stade Felix Houphouet-Boigny on Tuesday in Group D of the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers.
